newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore gets support for multimedia network.
newsitem.headline: Singapore gets support for multimedia network.

text.p: Singapore has secured the commitment of 14 multi-national corporations to help it build a national high-capacity multimedia network, the National Computer Board (NCB) said on Thursday.
The network, called Singapore ONE, aims to bring widespread multimedia services and applications to Singapore homes, at the workplace and in school.
The 14 companies have committed to provide various interactive, multimedia applications and services on the broadband network.

They are Andersen Consulting, Bloomberg, Electronic Arts Inc., Global Knowledge Network, Hewlett-Packard Co, International Business Machines Corp, Microsoft Corp, Motorola Multimedia Group, Music Pen, NEC Singapore, Oracle Corp, Reuters Holdings Plc, Sun Microsystems Inc and Yahoo! Inc.
At the memorandum of understanding signing ceremony between the multi-national corporations and NCB, Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said the government could not realise Singapore ONE alone.
"It needs partners to contribute technology and ideas, build the infrastructure, and develop and deploy compelling applications," he said.
He said the total investment over the next two years from the 14 multi-national corporations would exceed S$100 million (US$71 million).

The projects the multi-national corporations will develop for the network over the next two years range from on-line educational and training packages, to information services and entertainment packages.
The government has also set up a "Pioneer Club" to encourage participation on the network.

Targeted at all companies which can commit to launch a commercial service or application by June 1998, the government will offer these companies a host of incentives including preferential tariffs to get on the network, and tax breaks.
